data.text: Contents
Incubation Period, Signs/Symptoms and Side Effects ................................................. 7
Introduction

Norovirus (also known as small round structured viruses, Norwalk, or the winter vomiting disease) is a highly infectious virus, particularly in enclosed settings such as hospitals, schools, nursing homes and cruise ships. It is more prominent during the winter months, but can occur at any time of year. It is readily spread from person to person through aerosol inhalation and environmental contamination from vomiting and diarrhoea.

Norovirus is the commonest cause of outbreaks of infectious gastroenteritis in hospitals, and is estimated to cost the NHS in excess of ￡100 million per annum, affecting approximately 1 million people each year in the UK, and causing major disruption to important and essential services (HICPAC 2011). Recent evidence suggests that implementation of robust Infection Prevention and Control strategies may help to prevent prolonged ward/departmental closures, reduce disruption to essential services, reduce transmission of the infection and maximise the organisation's ability to deliver appropriate care to
patients, safely and effectively (Norovirus Working Party 2011).
Purpose

To provide Trust staff with guidance for effective management of patients suffering from gastroenteritis and the prevention of transmission to other patients, staff, visitors and contamination of the environment.
Definitions

table_items.text: Director of Infection Prevention and Control
Using the Bristol Stool Chart – an episode of type 6 or 7 stool
A highly contagious small round structured virus capable of causing symptoms of diarrhoea and/or vomiting.
Two or more patients with a common exposure to a potential source, who are affected by a similar illness or proven infection

A final level of cleaning used in health care environments required to help control the spread of infection. The level of cleaning required to denote the end of an outbreak prior to re‐opening of wards/affected areas

data.text: Duties

Site Infection Prevention and Control Committee (IPCC's) is responsible for the review of this policy at least every two years, but more frequently if there are changes to Infection Prevention and Control Legislation or guidance.

The Chief Executive has overall responsibility for ensuring the Trust has the necessary management systems in place to enable the effective implementation of this policy and overall responsibility for the health and safety of staff, patients and visitors.
The Director for Infection Prevention and Control (DIPC)
The DIPC is the Trust Director responsible to the board for the delivery of IPC standards.
MSE Lead IPC
Has operational responsibly for the effective implementation of this policy.
The Infection Prevention and Control Teams (IPCT's)

The IPCT's will act as a resource for information and support. They will provide education in relation to this policy which includes mandatory training. They will monitor the implementation of this policy via audit within clinical areas.
Clinical Site Managers

The Clinical Site Managers are responsible for ensuring suspected cases of Norovirus are isolated in accordance with this policy and to ensure there is no inappropriate movement of patients unless there is an urgent clinical need.
Occupational Health Department

On receiving report from member of staff that they are ill, Occupational Health Staff should record the episode in the staff record and offer advice, according to policy, on when it is appropriate for staff member to return to work.
Ward Staff
Ward staff are required to be vigilant for all cases of diarrhoea and report any cases of suspected infectious diarrhoea to the IPCT or Clinical Site Managers out of hours.
4.8.1 Ward staff are responsible for ensuring stool specimens are collected and submitted promptly and that the completion of the relevant documentation has been carried out i.e. stool charts.

4.8.2 Ward staff working on those wards which are affected with Norovirus, are responsible for reporting and recording details of patients with suspected Norovirus and providing an up to date list on a daily basis to the IPCT
Individual Staff

All employees will comply with this policy and inform the Infection Prevention and Control Team about any issues or concerns relating to the policy. All staff will be up to date with mandatory Infection Prevention and Control training.

4.9.1  Infection control is the responsibility of ALL staff associated with patient care. A high standard of infection control is required on ALL wards and units, although the level of risk may vary. It is an important part of total patient care.
Incubation Period, Signs/Symptoms and Side Effects

The period from when a person is infected to when they start to show symptoms of Norovirus (known as the incubation period) usually lasts ‐ hours. During this time, they may be infectious to other people and will continue to be infectious up to 48 hours after symptoms stop.
The illness is characterized by:
Sudden onset vomiting (may be projectile)
Sudden onset of watery diarrhoea and abdominal cramps
Nausea

In addition; headache, myalgia (muscle ache), fever and malaise are common. Some or all of the above symptoms may be present. Symptoms last between one and three days and recovery is usually rapid. Dehydration is the most common complication and patients may require replacement fluids.
Transmission

Noroviruses are highly contagious with as few as 100 virus particles thought to be sufficient to cause infection. They are transmitted primarily through the faecal – oral route, either by person to person contact or via contaminated food or water. In addition, Noroviruses can spread via aerosol dissemination of infected particles following vomiting.

Transmission can also occur through hand transfer of the virus to the oral mucosa following contact with environmental surfaces and equipment, which have been contaminated with either faeces or vomit. Patients are most infectious during the early stages when diarrhoea and vomiting is profuse.
Diagnosis
Diagnosis of Norovirus infection can often be made on clinical grounds from their characteristic features, but confirmation requires testing of a stool sample.
When an outbreak is suspected, it is imperative to commence Infection Control measures immediately, without waiting for virological confirmation from stool testing.
Precautions in Emergency Departments (ED's)

Precautions must be taken as soon as possible to prevent the spread of infection. Therefore, patients presenting to ED, with acute vomiting and or / diarrhoea should be triaged and moved straight into a side room/cubicle. The door/curtains must be kept shut (spread can be airborne if patient is vomiting). Symptomatic patients must be assessed promptly. Patients should be discharged home if it is clinically appropriate; not every case of Norovirus needs admission.

If the patient requires admission and the diagnosis is suspected Norovirus, the Clinical Site Manager must liaise with the Infection Prevention and Control Team (IPCT) for advice or Consultant Microbiologist

Patients must be admitted into a single room, with ensuite facilities, if side room unavailable, please seek urgent IPCT advice. During a Norovirus outbreak, patients presenting with suspected Norovirus must be admitted to a side room, or if applicable, to the most recently closed Ward (IPCT to advise). This negates the risk of dispersing Norovirus cases throughout the hospital.
Action by ward/departmental staff

Effective communication is essential at all times during a suspected or confirmed outbreak. On suspicion of a possible outbreak, (2 or more cases of unexplained diarrhoea and / or vomiting on a ward/department, either patients or staff), the ward manager or nurse in charge must ensure the collection of accurate information on affected patients and/or affected staff (appendix 1 and 2). This form is available electronically on STAFFnet/HUB/ Intranet
Initial assessment by the Infection Prevention and Control
Team

All suspected outbreaks reported to the Infection Prevention and Control Team will be given priority over other work, and a visit made to the area as soon as possible. After an initial assessment by the IPCN the situation will be discussed with the DIPC and/or Microbiologist, and a decision will be taken as to whether to recommend ward closure, bay closure, or keep the ward under enhanced surveillance. Dependent upon the number of patients affected and the availability of side rooms on the ward, a decision will be made by the IPCN on whether to isolate affected patients or to leave them in their current bed space. When an outbreak is suspected the ward must avoid moving patients prior to the review by IPCN.

An IPCN will visit the ward daily, or more often if required, to assess the situation and set a written action plan for the next 24 hours. A generic email will be sent out each day from the IPCT to all relevant staff updating them on the outbreak situation.
Out of Hours (refer to Appendix 2)
If an outbreak is suspected out of hours the Nurse in charge must complete the Outbreak information sheet Appendix 1 (available electronically STAFFnet/HUB/Intranet)

Nurse in charge to inform the Clinical Site Manager once the outbreak information is obtained. CMS to liaise with the on-call ICN regarding actions required (Weekends /Bank Holiday 9-5) or Consultant Microbiologist on call
Measures required to contain an outbreak

The only proven measure to shorten an outbreak is to close the affected bay or ward to new patients. This avoids exposing further patients to the infection. The Infection Control Team / Consultant Microbiologist /DIPC are the only people with the designated responsibility to close and open a bay or ward as a result of an outbreak of infection.

Should more than one ward be affected by patients with diarrhoea and/or vomiting, the Infection Control Team/DIPC/Microbiologist in consultation with Trust senior management will convene an Outbreak Committee.
Documentation

Once a bay or ward has been closed as a result of a suspected/confirmed outbreak, it is the responsibility of the nurse in charge to ensure that the patient information sheet / staff sheet is completed documenting all NEW symptomatic patients or staff members. (Appendix 1 and 2). Accurate documentation of all symptomatic patients is vital in order for the IPCN to make an accurate assessment of the outbreak, and plan the correct course of management.
The following information is necessary for all symptomatic patients:
Full name
Admission date
Position on the ward; state bed number and bay or single room
Onset date of symptoms
Information such as recent antibiotic history, laxative history and other relevant information such as stoma PEG feed
Presenting symptoms
Date/time of stool specimen
Preventing the Spread of Infection and Personal Protective
Equipment
Personal Protective Equipment must be used when dealing with faeces and/or vomit, other body fluids and for direct patient contact
Any failure to comply with the wearing of protective clothing and hand washing during an outbreak should be notified to the Infection Prevention Control Team

There is no evidence to support the use of wearing face masks when caring for patients with suspected Norovirus. The use of masks may instil a false sense of security and are not a substitute for good Infection Control/standard precautions
Open bowls of fruit and other uncovered food should be removed, as they may become contaminated and become a source for more cases
Stool Samples

Stool testing for Norovirus is carried out only when an outbreak is suspected. This will be arranged by the IPCN. Testing for Norovirus is not carried out at the Trust. Stool samples are sent to Addenbrooks Hospital, Cambridge, for processing. Results for positive samples are telephoned to the relevant laboratory service as soon as they are identified. The turnaround time for this is approximately 1-2 days.

Stool samples are required from patients with diarrhoea. If the sample is contaminated with urine it can still be sent. Faeces can be removed from the sheet or incontinence pad if it is not possible to obtain a sample from the bedpan. All samples which are liquid will be tested for Clostridioides difficile as a matter of routine.
Vomit is not suitable for testing and must not be sent to the laboratory.
Isolation
Dependent upon the number of symptomatic patients involved, patients will either be nursed in single rooms, or cohort nursed in a bay. The IPCN will advise on the need to isolate or cohort nurse.
Linen
All linen from isolation areas/affected wards must be treated as infected linen and placed in a red alginate liner and then placed in a white linen bag.
Hand Hygiene

The hands of healthcare staff are a vehicle for the transmission of infection. It is therefore essential that all staff wash their hands using the correct hand washing technique to help reduce the risk of transmission,

Alcohol gel Trust is effective against viruses and therefore must be used on entry and exit from a closed ward and before and after every patient contact. Hands must be washed with soap and water if visibly soiled or after contact with potentially infectious equipment, furnishings or other items. Gloves do not replace the need to wash hands. Patients must be provided with the opportunity to wash their hands, or use hand wipes, after each toileting episode and also before each meal.
Treatment

There is no effective treatment for Norovirus. It is a self-limiting illness which will cease within a few days. It is important to ensure prompt fluid replacement to prevent dehydration and its complications.
Preventing Spread to Other Areas
It is essential to restrict the movement of patients and staff from affected to unaffected areas.

Symptomatic and asymptomatic patients must not be transferred to other wards. However, if the patient needs to be transferred to another ward for clinical reason, such as a category 1 medical patient, the nurse in charge or the Clinical Site Manager must discuss this with the IPCT before the transfer takes place, and the patient must be isolated for at least 72 hours following their transfer or until they are symptom free for 72 hours.

Affected patients must not be discharged to nursing or residential homes until the outbreak ward is reopened. (Patients that have had Norovirus infection are regarded as infectious for 72 hours after the end of their illness). This is the case even if the patient being transferred does not have diarrhoea or
vomiting- as they may be incubating the infection. This is to avoid transmitting the infection to another institution
Affected patients may be discharged to their own homes once they are deemed fit for discharge.

If a patient requires transfer to another health care provider then their new carer must be informed of the situation prior to the transfer, to allow infection Prevention and Control arrangements to be put in place.

Staff working in affected areas must not work in unaffected areas until at least 48 hours after working in the affected area. This includes both bank and agency staff. Essential ward-based staff such as Physiotherapists, Occupational Therapists and Domestics should be dedicated to the affected area wherever possible.

If the clinical condition of a patient dictates their treatment requires them to be admitted to a ward closed with diarrhoea and vomiting, the admitting medical team has a responsibility to inform the patient of the ward status, and also to document in the patient's notes that their clinical condition outweighs their risk of entering a ward which is currently closed as a result of diarrhoea and vomiting.
Patients requiring urgent investigations or treatment outside
the ward

If a patient is symptomatic, his/her visit to another department should be delayed if clinical condition dictates, as it will be distressing for the patient if an episode of diarrhoea or vomiting occurs during transit. Furthermore, this will also unnecessarily expose more contacts to the infection. Alternatives should be considered such as portable X- ray.

There will be occasions when patients need to be sent to other departments for investigations or treatment which cannot be carried out on a closed ward. Patients should only be transferred for investigations and interventions that cannot be safely delayed. URGENT investigations must NOT be delayed. If patients require urgent tests/diagnostics such as X-ray or CT scans in other departments, this must be discussed with the patient's medical team, ward staff and the IPCT. It is the responsibility of the nurse in charge of the ward to ensure the receiving department is informed about the status of the patient, so they can ensure the patient's visit is brief.
Environmental cleaning

Whilst a ward is closed during an outbreak, the area must be cleaned daily with the Trust approved disinfectant solution. Special attention must be paid to toilet and bathroom areas, commodes, all horizontal surfaces and frequent touch surfaces such as door handles, flush handles, sinks, taps and nurse call systems. It is the responsibility of the nurse in charge to inform the domestic staff of requirements for their ward.
Health care workers f are responsible for ensuring that all equipment, including commodes are cleaned with between each patient use and labelled/stored as clean
Any empty beds should be stripped and not re-made until the ward is deep cleaned and re-opened.
Visitors

A ‘ward closed banner' will be placed at the entrance of the closed ward. The banner is a highly visible sign which provides information to visitors and staff that the ward is closed as a result of an infection. The sign informs staff and visitors of the situation, and asks them to report to the nurse in charge before seeing a patient. They should be asked to postpone their visit, or if essential for personal reasons, to make their stay as short as possible and not bring in food items. Visitors should be asked to decontaminate their hands on entry and before leaving the ward. Visitors must refrain from sitting on the bed whilst visiting.
Visitors must be advised not to come to the hospital if they are symptomatic
In the event of four or more wards being closed, the Trust will be closed to visitors
Closure to Visitors – Communications
In the event of a Trust closure to visitors, the Communications Team will attend relevant meetings and will:
Issue notification to all staff via; email to senior managers and / or all users
Issue notification to the media via broadcast and press publications as well as on the Trust website
Liaise with Facilities to ensure notices are placed around the Trust, and the Switchboard is made aware of our position to allow visitors
The Communications Team will liaise with local stakeholders such as the Communications Department at the local CCG to ensure they are aware of the action if the matter becomes protracted
The Communications department will also work with the Trust to stand the matter down at the relevant time.
Staff

Staff members experiencing sudden onset of diarrhoea and / or vomiting should avoid attending work at the hospital. If staff are due in to work or on the way into work, they should remain away and self-report the episode by telephone, firstly to their immediate manager or the nurse in charge.

If the staff member is already on duty at the hospital at the onset of an episode, they should inform their line manager or the nurse in charge and go home immediately, informing Occupational Health Department by telephone as soon as is practicable. In addition, as sudden explosive diarrhoea and or vomiting as a result of an infectious cause (particularly Norovirus), inevitably contaminates the immediate environment with particles heavily laden with virus, arrangements should be made, through the nurse in charge, if necessary, to cordon off the area/toilet concerned and call the rapid response team via switch board to have it cleaned before further use.
Exclusion from work

25.3.1 In order to reduce the chance of staff members returning to work and relapsing while on duty, all staff who are thought to have possible Norovirus or other infectious gastroenteritis, should be excluded from work until they are 48 hours symptom-free.
Staff with symptoms lasting for more than 3 days

25.4.1 Any staff with symptoms of diarrhoea and/or vomiting lasting for more than 3 days should seek further advice on diagnosis and treatment from their General Practitioner. Staff MUST NOT take stool samples to the Occupational Health Department.
Ward Re-Opening

An Outbreak can be declared as resolved when there have been no new cases in staff and patients for 72 hours, and when all patients have been asymptomatic for 72 hours. The final decision will be made by the Infection Prevention & Control Team/DIPC/ Consultant Microbiologist. (See appendix
The ward must not be declared open until a deep clean is completed to a satisfactory standard
The IPCT will inform relevant personnel via email, and ensure that the ward staff is aware of the plan for the terminal clean.
The IPCN will liaise with the Domestic Service Manager and the relevant Matron regarding planning the ward terminal clean and produce a written plan for the clean.
Once the decision has been made to clean the ward, patients can be discharged home, discharged back to residential care or transferred to other wards.

data.url: MSEPO-21034 Policy for management and control of diarrhoea and vomiting.003.png

data.text: New patients cannot be admitted to a ward whilst the cleaning is in progress as empty bed spaces/bays/rooms are required for decanting purposes and effective, safe cleaning of the ward/area.
Specialist ring-fenced beds can be considered for decanting to facilitate deep cleaning.
Domestic staff must:

Wear the appropriate Personal Protective Equipment (PPE) when undertaking the clean and must have received training in the use of all cleaning products and equipment. Disposable curtains to be changed (including window curtains)
The ward will be open to admissions once the clean has been completed and signed off.
Training requirements

All Trust staff to undertake Mandatory Infection Prevention and Control updates The IPCT has primary responsibility for providing training on the policy where needed. Managers have the responsibly to support the IPCT by ensuring that staff are able to attend training sessions in response to identified needs
Monitoring Compliance

table_items.text: Aspect of compliance or effectiveness being monitored
Individual/ department responsible for the monitoring
Group/commi ttee/ forum which will receive the findings/monitoring report
Committee/ individual responsible for ensuring that the actions are completed
Isolation precautions and availably of isolation facilities
Isolation Audit report presented to the IPCC

data.text: Approval and Implementation

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved by the Site Infection Prevention and Control Committees, which is the specialist group with the authority to approve local Policy/ guidelines. These will then be forwarded to the Document control team for submission and ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.
It is the author's responsibility to inform the Director Harm Free Care of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.
Equality Impact Assessment
The Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals.
(Refer to appendix 4)
References
Health Protection Agency (2007) Health Protection Network for the Detection and Characterisation of Noroviruses. Newsletter 1. July 2007.

Health Protection Agency (2011) Guidelines for the Management of Norovirus outbreaks in Acute and Community Health and social care settings http://www.hpa.org.uk/webw/HPAweb&HPAwebStandard/HPAweb_C/131713 1647275

Report of the Public Health Laboratory Service Vial Gastro Enteritis Working Group. Management hospital outbreaks of gastro-enteritis due to small round structured viruses. Journal of Hospital Infection (2000) 45.: 1-10.
Department of Health (2008) The Health Act 2006 Code of Practice for the Prevention and Control of Health Care Associated Infections (revised 2010). London. Department of Health.
